title: Cardinals manager Shildt address profane comments
text:
A day after Mike Shildt's profane postgame comments were posted online, the St. Louis Cardinals manager apologized for his language but not for his passion in his opening remarks at a news conference on Thursday.

The comments became public Wednesday night when Cardinals rookie outfielder Randy Arozarena posted an online video showing a profanity-laced speech from Shildt in the wake of the team's 13-1 win over the Atlanta Braves in the decisive Game 5 of the National League Division Series.

"You know, the clubhouse is a sanctuary that is very sacred, it's a private opportunity for us to be able to enjoy and celebrate," Shildt said. "And yesterday, I got a great opportunity to have a moment with our team that is private, should have been private, and make sure they knew how proud of the accomplishments they have and moving forward, to our staff and our players. You know, I apologize if my language offended anyone."

The Cardinals will open the NL Championship Series against the Washington Nationals on Friday. After the win over the Braves, Shildt spouted off to his team in the locker room and the remarks caused a firestorm once they became public.

"The (Braves) started some (expletive). We finished the (expletive), and that's how we roll," Shildt said. "No one (expletive) with us ever. Now, I don't give a (expletive) who we play. We're gonna (expletive) them up. We're gonna take it right to them the whole (expletive) way. We're gonna kick their (expletive) ass."

Arozarena, a 24-year-old Cuba native, posted the video on Instagram but later deleted it and posted an apology in Spanish.

The subsequent text, translated to English, read, "I want to apologize to my teammates, manager, the Cardinals Organization and baseball fans for the video I posted tonight after the victory of our team in Atlanta. This was a moment that should have been private with my team and I made a rookie mistake by sharing it on my social media account."

Shildt said the salty language is something he is trying to cut down on and he said it was regrettable that the video became public.

"It's not something I like to represent, it's not to be excused, it's supposed to be a private moment," Shildt said. "But I will say that I'm flawed, I have my moments. I grew up in a clubhouse and one of the crosses I bear is my language. So I have done a nice job over the many years of curbing that and trying to represent always this organization and myself in a positive light, with class and dignity. I feel like I've always done that.

"It was regretful that that was able to get out. I will not apologize for having passion about how I feel about our team and the accomplishments of our team. So I just want to get that out there. It's not anything I want to talk about moving forward, we got baseball to play."

Arozarena appeared in the first 19 games of his major league career this season, going 6-for-20 (.300) with one homer and two RBIs. He made substitute appearances in the NLDS, finishing 0-for-3.

Shildt, 51, is in his first full season as the Cardinals' manager. He took over in the middle of 2018 and produced a 41-28 mark, then led St. Louis to a 91-71 record this year and the NL Central championship.

--Field Level Media
